node.text:
.
Since the world tells us in a thousand different ways that our bodies are broken, wrong, out of control, and less-than, it’s important to have someone remind us that it’s our world that’s crazy: We're not crazy, we're goddamn cheetahs. 

That someone for me is usually my sister. Here's Amanda’s gentle reminder from this week’s episode about why BMI is horseshit. 

We can do hard things. Like learn to wage peace with our bodies in a world that insists we be at war with ourselves. Listen at the link in my bio.

node.text:
I read this section of UNTAMED in a steepled, echoing church sanctuary on the first night of the book tour right before our world changed. That night, a thousand people looked on, but I shared it for one person—my wife—who sat in the front pew that night.

In this week’s podcast episode, Abby opens her soul and pain and healing story to us.

No one, but no one, has more God in them than you do—so be brave. No one, but no one, has less God in them than you do—so be kind.

Listen to We Can Do Hard Things at the link in my bio.

node.text:
Y'all we're recording a We Can Do Hard Things podcast episode about sex this week and we want to know what you'd like to hear us address. Questions? Topics? What should we talk about!???
We love you. This is hard for me but we can do hard things. I want this part of our lives to be less taboo and confusing and lonely. 
Kay!!! Go!!!

node.text:
.
Today on the We Can Do Hard Things podcast, we have the most intimate conversation we've ever had. Abby shares about how she learned as a child from her beloved church to hate herself, and how she healed. 

This episode is for anyone who has been through the trauma of being abandoned by, or had to leave, a beloved, foundational community. 

For anyone who has had to choose between who they are and who they love. 

For anyone who is still healing from the internalized self-hate they were fed by people they trusted. 

For anyone who has been told ““I disagree with your lifestyle, but I love you anyway.”

For anyone who doesn’t yet know who their children will become, but is hellbent on protecting whatever they will be. 

For anyone who—notwithstanding all the messages from the world—knows we all deserve to be both held and free; to fully belong exactly as we are.

This episode is for all of us.  Listen at the link in my bio. 

Thank you, Abby, for opening your soul and pain and healing to us. I love you.
G

node.text:
Well, hello, my night owl friends,
Do you happen to be, like my sister Amanda, a “revenge bedtime procrastinator” — exhausted and spent but still spending countless hours scrolling social media while you “should” be sleeping because you're so starved for anything that remotely resembles an exhale and it’s the only damn time you get to yourself and by yourself?

You’re not alone. 

Talking about how we can care for ourselves and our needs in this week’s We Can Do Hard Things podcast — listen at the link in my bio. 

Love,
G

node.text:
.
New We Can Do Hard Things episode!  Listen at the link in my bio. 
 
Today we are talking about SELF CARE.
 
We know in our bones that we must prioritize caring for our selves.  And the 450 Billion dollar self care industry is thrilled to intercede — relentlessly selling us their commodified version.

But what is real, deep, inner self care and how do we begin to actually see ourselves and identify our real needs enough to finally get them met? 
 
Listen at the link in my bio as my sister Amanda and I discuss:
1️⃣ How to create lives that we don’t need to escape from.
2️⃣ Why our resentment toward others is our Secret Self-Care Signal.
3️⃣ Why ditching selflessness is the best way to care for others and the world.
4️⃣ How to stop passing down the brutal legacy of martyrdom to our children and
5️⃣ My life-changing spiritual practice: Habitual Quitting.
 
We Can Do Hard Things. Like know our needs and get them met. 
G

node.text:
.
In this week’s We Can Do Hard Things podcast, Abby and I talk about the hard thing of FIGHTING WELL and how we learned that whenever we entered conflict, we would each suit up with a “bulletproof vest” to try to make ourselves invulnerable.  

My bulletproof vest is anger and rightness – my instinct is to fight like a lawyer hellbent on winning her case, instead of a partner trying to get to resolution.  

Abby’s bulletproof vest is shame and fear of abandonment.

We put on these bulletproof vests so we won’t expose our vulnerability – but wearing them makes it absolutely impossible to even talk about – much less resolve – the original conflict, because now we’re just dealing with, and fighting about, each other’s armor.  

Did you listen to this episode?  Did the bulletproof vest resonate with you?  If so, what’s yours?

We Can Do Hard Things: Like Fight Well with the ones we love. 
Listen at the link in my bio.  
G
@abbywambach

Abby is back joining us in this week’s episode of We Can Do Hard Things! (Listen at the link in my bio.)

We talk about the five fights we have most often, how our fights usually go – and how we finally started FIGHTING WELL. 
 
In our relationship, Abby used to run from conflict.  I do not, thank you very much. In fact, if I were to ever run anywhere (I will not), it would be TOWARD CONFLICT.  As you can imagine, this took some navigating. 
 
Even though my sister Amanda is usually on Abby’s side, she helped explain the value we pro-conflict folks bring to our relationships.
 
When it comes to conflict in your relationships, are you Team Abby (conflict is destructive), or Team Glennon (conflict is constructive)?

I love you @abbywambach. I want to fight with you forever. 

Listen and follow We Can Do Hard Things at the link in my bio.
G

node.text:
.
NEW EPISODE OF THE WE CAN DO HARD THINGS PODCAST OUT TODAY. 
Click the link in bio to listen! 

OVERWHELM: Is our exhaustion a sign that we’re CareTicking time bombs?

If you are overwhelmed as the default family caretaker—it’s not because you're doing it wrong.
It’s because, as my sister Amanda says, “structurally, the way this gig is set up is horseshit.”

In this episode discover:
1️⃣ How the constant to-do list ticker looping in Amanda's brain makes her feel like a dormant volcano.
2️⃣ The job description we've somehow accepted for motherhood—and whether self-abandonment is a job requirement.
3️⃣ The way gender expectations even creep into Glennon and Abby's marriage.
4️⃣ How to know whether your partner is a co-builder or an assistant.
5️⃣ How to make the invisible load of caretaking visible—and potentially bearable. 

Listen at the link in bio and leave a review if you have time! Thank you for your support and encouragement. It means the world to us.

Isn’t it music?

Isn’t it music that sneaks deep inside, taps awake our soul, and reminds us that we’re still alive in there?

If music is not your jam, what are the things you do to come alive? Let us know! HELP US OUT! 

To listen to this week’s podcast, go to the link in my bio.

When "manners" and kindness turn out to be two different things: let's choose kindness. 

For your consideration, with love and grace. 

G

node.text:
What if they get mad? 
What if they don't understand? What if they leave?

They might. I've certainly lost people. What I've learned is that the people I lose when I refuse to lose myself are the people I was meant to lose. And the people I find are the people I was meant to find. And with them: I can be both held and free. 

I didn't pretend to get them so I don't have to pretend to keep them.

It's hard to refuse to abandon yourself. But it's also hard to abandon yourself. It's all hard. So I guess we just gotta choose our hard. 

Anyway. I just love ya. You're doing great under this RIDICULOUS set of circumstances we call: life. 

XO, 
G

#GetUntamed

node.text:
.
Since the world tells us in a thousand different ways that our bodies are broken, wrong, out of control, and less-than, it’s important to have someone remind us that it’s our world that’s crazy: We're not crazy, we're goddamn cheetahs. 

That someone for me is usually my sister. Here's Amanda’s gentle reminder from this week’s episode about why BMI is horseshit. 

We can do hard things. Like learn to wage peace with our bodies in a world that insists we be at war with ourselves. Listen at the link in my bio.

node.text:
.
From Tish:
I wrote this song because I wanted to remind people that they can get through hard times. I thought maybe if people listened, they could be inspired to keep trying. It’s funny because I wrote it to encourage you, but your support has encouraged ME to keep writing music and keep trying, too. I hope to have new music for you to listen to soon!

To be loved, we need to be known. Thank you for getting to know me. 
Tish 

P.S. Thank you to @BrandiCarlile for believing in me and producing my first ever single!

We Can Do Hard Things is now available for streaming and download. Search “We Can Do Hard Things” or “Tish Melton” on iTunes, Spotify, Amazon Music, Pandora, YouTube, or go through the link in my bio.

node.text:
Listen at the link in my bio to today's We Can Do Hard Things conversation as we explore how the world’s war against women becomes a world full of women at war with our own bodies. How do we wave the white flag and begin to wage peace?
 
I've struggled my entire life to be comfortable in my own skin. As a girl, I learned how to be wanted, but not how to want. I learned to care about what I looked like more than I care about what I'm looking at. I learned that my worthiness was in my appearance, and that to be beautiful, a woman needed to stay small in ambition and desire and appetite and emotion and voice and body.

I tried hard to follow the directions. I was severely bulimic from age 10 to 26, and I stopped bingeing and purging when I got sober almost 19 years ago. Now I'm 45 years old. And just last month I cried to Abby and told her that I bet that throughout a typical day, especially during COVID, it felt like 80% of my thoughts were still about food and my body.
It makes me embarrassed as a feminist. It makes me enraged as a human being because of the opportunity costs of spending so much of my life on this. I cannot imagine the thoughts I would think, the art I'd make, and the activism I'd unleash, if I had that time and mind space back.

I want us to unlearn body hate and learn to inhabit, love, and trust our bodies. Let's try. We can do hard things.

***This episode includes raw, real talk about disordered eating. If that kind of talk heals you, listen up. But if that kind of talk triggers you, skip this one, or save it to listen in a safe place with safe people. Please first take care of you.***

Listen at the link in my bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glennon Doyle on July 11, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and dog.

node.text:
Night Night Love Bugs. Sleep tight. All is well. We begin again tomorrow. 
G, A, and H

node.text:
I read this section of UNTAMED in a steepled, echoing church sanctuary on the first night of the book tour right before our world changed. That night, a thousand people looked on, but I shared it for one person—my wife—who sat in the front pew that night.

In this week’s podcast episode, Abby opens her soul and pain and healing story to us.

No one, but no one, has more God in them than you do—so be brave. No one, but no one, has less God in them than you do—so be kind.

Listen to We Can Do Hard Things at the link in my bio.

node.text:
Y'all we're recording a We Can Do Hard Things podcast episode about sex this week and we want to know what you'd like to hear us address. Questions? Topics? What should we talk about!???
We love you. This is hard for me but we can do hard things. I want this part of our lives to be less taboo and confusing and lonely. 
Kay!!! Go!!!

Q: Glennon, can I still love you and disagree with your lifestyle?
Me: No.

Listen at the link in my bio

node.text:
.
Today on the We Can Do Hard Things podcast, we have the most intimate conversation we've ever had. Abby shares about how she learned as a child from her beloved church to hate herself, and how she healed. 

This episode is for anyone who has been through the trauma of being abandoned by, or had to leave, a beloved, foundational community. 

For anyone who has had to choose between who they are and who they love. 

For anyone who is still healing from the internalized self-hate they were fed by people they trusted. 

For anyone who has been told ““I disagree with your lifestyle, but I love you anyway.”

For anyone who doesn’t yet know who their children will become, but is hellbent on protecting whatever they will be. 

For anyone who—notwithstanding all the messages from the world—knows we all deserve to be both held and free; to fully belong exactly as we are.

This episode is for all of us.  Listen at the link in my bio. 

Thank you, Abby, for opening your soul and pain and healing to us. I love you.

node.text:
Abby has lived and breathed the beautiful game since she stepped on to a soccer field when she was five years old and scored 27 goals in her first three games. Since that debut, she continued to find her power, her purpose, and her people on the pitch. When Peyton Manning asked if she would be the one to make the case to the world that Soccer Is Love, she was scared but she said: Yes. I was born to do this.

Abby stepped way out of her comfort zone for this show. I watched her make herself vulnerable, try things she’d never tried before, and show up before she was ready—all for the love of this game that has loved her so well for so long.
 
I am so proud of Abby and so excited that the world will now get to see soccer through her eyes. When you watch ABBY’S PLACES, you will see her humor, heart, and passion light up the screen. You’ll feel it. Soccer might be love, but so is @AbbyWambach.
 
Watch ABBY’S PLACES on ESPN+ this Wednesday 7/7.

P.S. Abby’s show is on ESPN+, not ESPN—so even if you don't get ESPN, you might already have ESPN+
@espn
